6.1. Coronary Revascularization Before Noncardiac Surgery: Recommendations

Class I

Revascularization before noncardiac surgery is recommended in circumstances in which revascularization is indicated according to existing CPGs. 25,26 ( Level of Evidence: C ) (See Table A in Appendix 3 for related recommendations.)

Class III: No Benefit

It is not recommended that routine coronary revascularization be performed before noncardiac surgery exclusively to reduce perioperative cardiac events. 116 (Level of Evidence: B)

Patients undergoing risk stratification before elective noncardiac procedures and whose evaluation recommends CABG surgery should undergo coronary revascularization before an elevated-risk surgical procedure. 227 The cumulative mortality and morbidity risks of both the coronary revascularization procedure and the noncardiac surgery should be weighed carefully in light of the individual patient's overall health, functional status, and prognosis. The indications for preoperative surgical coronary revascularization are identical to those recommended in the 2011 CABG CPG and the 2011 PCI CPG and the accumulated data on which those conclusions were based 25,26 (See Table A in Appendix 3 for the related recommendations).", "source": "2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md", "page": null, "chunk_id": "bd0cc243-392a-499f-a1d1-9bd5fc4ace9c"}, {"content": "Duceppe et al.

Perioperative Cardiac Risk Assessment & Management

27

The trial that is more broadly applicable to patients who undergo noncardiac surgery is the C oronary A rtery R evascularization P rophylaxis (CARP) trial. 71 This trial randomized 510 patients with known signi /uniFB01 cant coronary artery disease to preoperative coronary revascularization vs no coronary revascularization before vascular surgery. At a median of 2.7 years after randomization, mortality was 22% in the coronary revascularization group and 23% in the no-revascularization group (RR, 0.98; 95% CI, 0.70-1.37; P ¼ 0.92). Vascular surgery was undertaken a median of 48 days after coronary artery bypass grafting surgery and 41 days after PCI. The CARP trial excluded patients with left main coronary artery disease.

RECOMMENDATION

For patients with stable coronary artery disease who undergo noncardiac surgery, we recommend against preoperative prophylactic coronary revascularization (Strong Recommendation; Low-Quality Evidence).

Values and preferences. In the absence of clearly demonstrated bene /uniFB01 t, the potential for surgical delays, increase in costs, and risk of bleeding with dual antiplatelet therapy supported a strong recommendation against prophylactic preoperative coronary revascularization.

Practical tip. In patients with CCS class III-IV or unstable angina, obtaining coronary revascularization before noncardiac surgery seems prudent; however, an individual risk-bene /uniFB01 t assessment is required in patients who require urgent/semiurgent noncardiac surgery. Patients who receive PCI and a coronary stent should ideally have their noncardiac surgery delayed until the risks of stopping dual antiplatelet therapy are outweighed by the risks associated with delaying noncardiac surgery. 72,73

Performing PCI before noncardiac surgery should be limited to 1) patients with left main disease whose comorbidities preclude bypass surgery without undue risk and 2) patients with unstable CAD who would be appropriate candidates for emergency or urgent revascularization. 25,26 Patients with ST-elevation MI or non-ST-elevation acute coronary syndrome benefit from early invasive management. 26 In such patients, in whom noncardiac surgery is time sensitive despite an increased risk in the perioperative period, a strategy of balloon angioplasty or bare-metal stent (BMS) implantation should be considered.

There are no prospective RCTs supporting coronary revascularization, either CABG or PCI, before noncardiac surgery to decrease intraoperative and postoperative cardiac events. In the largest RCT, CARP (Coronary Artery Revascularization Prophylaxis), there were no differences in perioperative and long-term cardiac outcomes with or without preoperative coronary revascularization by CABG or PCI in patients with documented CAD, with the exclusion of those with left main disease, a LVEF <20%, and severe AS. 116 A follow-up analysis reported improved outcomes in the subset who underwent CABG compared with those who underwent PCI. 228 In an additional analysis of the database of patients who underwent coronary angiography in both the randomized and nonrandomized portion of the CARP trial, only the subset of patients with unprotected left main disease showed a benefit from preoperative coronary artery revascularization. 229 A second RCT also demonstrated no benefit from preoperative testing and directed coronary revascularization in patients with 1 to 2 risk factors for CAD, 230 but the conduct of the trial was questioned at the time of the GWC's discussions. 9", "source": "2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md", "page": null, "chunk_id": "01244e7d-0c08-4806-bb75-e5df99acd8e4"}, {"content": "Yes

In nonoperative settings, treatment strategies such as PCI (with or without stenting), CABG surgery, and medical therapy have proven e ffi cacious in improving long-term morbidity and mortality. Patients with signi fi cant ischemic heart disease who come for noncardiac surgery are likely to be candidates for one or more of these therapies regardless of their need for surgery. Optimal medical management can improve perioperative outcomes. Coronary intervention should be guided by the patient's cardiac condition and by the potential consequences of delaying surgery for recovery from the revascularization.

CORONARY ARTERY BYPASS GRAFTING

For CABG surgery to be bene fi cial before noncardiac surgery, the institutional risk of that particular noncardiac operation should be greater than the combined risk of coronary catheterization and coronary revascularization, plus the generally reported risk of that noncardiac operation. Th e indications for preoperative surgical coronary revascularization are the same as those in the nonoperative setting.

PERCUTANEOUS CORONARY INTERVENTION

It was thought that PCI before elective noncardiac surgery could improve perioperative outcomes. However, PCI, which is now o ft en accompanied by stenting and dual antiplatelet therapy, poses its own unique set of problems that need to be considered in patients who are scheduled to undergo elective noncardiac surgery. question: should patients with stable heart failure undergo additional preoperative evaluation before noncardiac surgery?
expected_answer: Yes, patients with stable heart failure should undergo evaluation and optimization before surgery.
ground_truth_sources: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md
rag_answer:
**Should patients with stable heart failure undergo additional preoperative evaluation before noncardiac surgery?** According to the 2014 ACC/AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery, patients with stable heart failure do not necessarily require additional preoperative evaluation before noncardiac surgery [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]. However, the guideline emphasizes the importance of careful patient selection, risk stratification, and shared decision-making between the patient, surgeon, anesthesiologist, and primary caregiver [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]. For patients with stable heart failure, the guideline suggests that routine preoperative evaluation, including electrocardiography (ECG), may not be necessary unless there are specific risk factors or clinical concerns [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]. Some studies suggest that preoperative ECG abnormalities do not predict postoperative cardiac complications in geriatric surgical patients [Liu LL, Dzankic S, Leung JM. Preoperative electrocardiogram abnormalities do not predict postoperative cardiac complications in geriatric surgical patients. J Am Geriatr Soc. 2002;50:1186-91]. On the other hand, other studies suggest that preoperative risk stratification using functional status, comorbidities, and other factors can help predict perioperative outcomes in patients with heart failure [Crawford RS, Cambria RP, Abularrage CJ, et al. Preoperative functional status predicts perioperative outcomes after infrainguinal bypass surgery. J Vasc Surg. 2010;51:351-8]. **Key recommendations:** 1. Careful patient selection and risk stratification are essential for patients with stable heart failure undergoing noncardiac surgery.
2. Routine preoperative evaluation, including ECG, may not be necessary unless specific risk factors or clinical concerns are present.
3. Preoperative risk stratification using functional status, comorbidities, and other factors can help predict perioperative outcomes in patients with heart failure. **Limitations:** 1. The available evidence is based on studies that may not be directly applicable to all patients with stable heart failure.
2. The guidelines emphasize the importance of individualized decision-making and shared decision-making between the patient, surgeon, anesthesiologist, and primary caregiver. **Important considerations:** 1. Patients with stable heart failure should be evaluated on a case-by-case basis, taking into account their individual risk factors and clinical concerns.
2. The decision to pursue additional preoperative evaluation should be made in consultation with the patient, surgeon, anesthesiologist, and primary caregiver. **References:** [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md] **Disclaimer:** This answer is based on the provided context and is intended to provide evidence-based guidance. However, it is essential to consult with the patient's primary caregiver and other relevant specialists to make informed decisions regarding preoperative evaluation and risk stratification.

question: is exercise stress testing recommended for asymptomatic patients undergoing low-risk noncardiac surgery?
expected_answer: No, routine stress testing is not recommended for asymptomatic patients undergoing low-risk surgery.
ground_truth_sources: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md
rag_answer:
**Exercise Stress Testing for Asymptomatic Patients Undergoing Low-Risk Noncardiac Surgery** Based on the provided clinical guidelines and medical literature, the recommendation for exercise stress testing in asymptomatic patients undergoing low-risk noncardiac surgery is as follows: * Routine screening with noninvasive stress testing is not useful for patients at low risk for noncardiac surgery. * For patients with elevated risk and excellent functional capacity, it is reasonable to forgo further exercise testing and proceed to surgery. * However, for patients with elevated risk and poor or unknown functional capacity, it may be reasonable to perform exercise testing with cardiac imaging to assess for myocardial ischemia. In the absence of specific clinical risk factors or poor functional capacity, exercise stress testing may not be necessary for asymptomatic patients undergoing low-risk noncardiac surgery. **Key Takeaways:** * Routine screening with noninvasive stress testing is not recommended for low-risk noncardiac surgery.
* Exercise stress testing may be considered for patients with elevated risk and poor or unknown functional capacity.
* For patients with excellent functional capacity and elevated risk, further exercise testing may not be necessary. **Patient Safety Considerations:** * Patients with poor or unknown functional capacity may benefit from further evaluation, including exercise stress testing with cardiac imaging.
* Asymptomatic patients with low-risk noncardiac surgery may not require exercise stress testing if they have excellent functional capacity and no specific clinical risk factors. **Recommendations:** * For patients with low-risk noncardiac surgery and excellent functional capacity, proceed to surgery without further evaluation.
* For patients with elevated risk and poor or unknown functional capacity, consider exercise stress testing with cardiac imaging to assess for myocardial ischemia.
* For patients with elevated risk and excellent functional capacity, forgo further exercise testing and proceed to surgery.
reasoning: The RAG model's answer is mostly correct, providing a clear and accurate summary of the recommendations for exercise stress testing in asymptomatic patients undergoing low-risk noncardiac surgery. However, it could be more concise and directly address the question, stating that routine stress testing is not recommended for asymptomatic patients undergoing low-risk surgery, which is the expected answer.

[{"content": "Class III: No Benefit

Routine screening with noninvasive stress testing is not useful for patients at low risk for noncardiac surgery. 165,166 (Level of Evidence: B)

Several studies have examined the role of exercise testing to identify patients at risk for perioperative complications. 162-164,167-170 Almost all of these studies were conducted in patients undergoing peripheral vascular surgery, because these patients are generally considered to be at the highest risk. 162,164,167-169 Although they were important contributions at the time, the outcomes in most of these studies are not reflective of contemporary perioperative event rates, nor was the patient management consistent with current standards of preventive and perioperative cardiac care. Furthermore, many used stress protocols that are not commonly used today, such as non-Bruce protocol treadmill tests or arm ergometry. However, from the available data, patients able to achieve approximately 7 METs to 10 METs have a low risk of perioperative cardiovascular events, 162,164 and those achieving <4 METs to 5 METs have an increased risk of perioperative cardiovascular events. 163,164 Electrocardiographic changes with exercise are not as predictive. 162-164,169

The vast majority of data on the impact of inducible myocardial ischemia on perioperative outcomes are based on pharmacological stress testing (Sections 5.5.1-5.5.3), but it seems reasonable that exercise stress echocardiography or radionuclide myocardial perfusion imaging (MPI) would perform similarly to pharmacological stress testing in patients who are able to exercise adequately.

See Online Data Supplement 11 for additional information on exercise stress testing for myocardial ischemia and functional capacity.

5.4. Cardiopulmonary Exercise Testing: Recommendation

Class IIb

question: should patients with atrial fibrillation continue anticoagulation therapy during the perioperative period?
expected_answer: Yes, anticoagulation should generally be continued or bridged, depending on thromboembolic risk.
ground_truth_sources: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md
rag_answer:
**Perioperative Management of Anticoagulation Therapy in Patients with Atrial Fibrillation** The management of anticoagulation therapy in patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) during the perioperative period is a complex issue. To address this question, we will consider several clinical guidelines and studies. **Risk of Thromboembolism in AF** Atrial fibrillation increases the risk of thromboembolism, with a 6-fold increased risk compared to patients in sinus rhythm [Source: Anesthesia Notes.md]. This increased risk is due to stasis of blood in the left atrium, which predisposes to clot formation. **Guidelines for Antithrombotic Therapy** The 2014 ACC/AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md] recommends a risk-based approach to antithrombotic therapy in patients with AF. This approach considers the patient's risk factors for thromboembolism, including heart failure, left ventricular ejection fraction less than 35%, and history of hypertension. **Continuation of Anticoagulation Therapy** The available evidence suggests that patients with AF should continue anticoagulation therapy during the perioperative period, unless there are specific contraindications to anticoagulation. * A study by Holbrook et al. found that continuation of anticoagulation therapy during surgery is associated with a reduced risk of thromboembolism.
* Another study by Skolarus et al. found that periprocedural interruptions in warfarin therapy are associated with an increased risk of thromboembolism. **Management of Anticoagulation Therapy** In patients with AF, the management of anticoagulation therapy during the perioperative period should be individualized, taking into account the patient's specific risk factors for thromboembolism and bleeding. * For patients who are at high risk of thromboembolism, continuation of anticoagulation therapy with warfarin or a novel oral anticoagulant (NOAC) is recommended.
* For patients who are at high risk of bleeding, temporary discontinuation of anticoagulation therapy may be considered, but this should be done under close supervision and with careful monitoring of the patient's risk factors. **Conclusion** In conclusion, patients with atrial fibrillation should continue anticoagulation therapy during the perioperative period, unless there are specific contraindications to anticoagulation. The management of anticoagulation therapy should be individualized, taking into account the patient's specific risk factors for thromboembolism and bleeding. **References** * Holbrook A, Schulman S, Witt DM, et al. Evidence-based management of anticoagulant therapy: Antithrombotic Therapy and Prevention of Thrombosis, 9th ed: American College of Chest Physicians Evidence-Based Clinical Practice Guidelines. Chest. 2012;141:e152S-84S.
* Skolarus LE, Morgenstern LB, Froehlich JB, et al. Guideline-discordant periprocedural interruptions in warfarin therapy. Circ Cardiovasc Qual Outcomes. 2011;4:206-10.
* Anesthesia Notes.md (Source: Anesthesia Notes.md)

The answer accurately concludes that patients with atrial fibrillation should continue anticoagulation therapy during the perioperative period, unless there are specific contraindications to anticoagulation.

question: is it recommended to measure preoperative natriuretic peptides in high-risk patients undergoing vascular surgery?
expected_answer: Yes, measurement of natriuretic peptides may be useful in high-risk vascular surgery patients.
ground_truth_sources: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md
rag_answer:
**Recommendation for Measuring Preoperative Natriuretic Peptides in High-Risk Patients Undergoing Vascular Surgery** According to the 2014 ACC/AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery, preoperative natriuretic peptide levels independently predict cardiovascular events in the first 30 days after vascular surgery [1]. Specifically, measurement of biomarkers, especially natriuretic peptides, may be helpful in assessing patients with heart failure (HF) and with diagnosing HF as a postoperative complication in patients at high risk for HF [2]. A systematic review and individual patient data meta-analysis found that preoperative and postoperative B-type natriuretic peptides (BNP) significantly improved the predictive performance of the Revised Cardiac Risk Index (RCRI) for perioperative cardiac events [3]. Another study found that plasma N-terminal pro-B-type natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) was an independent predictor of postoperative cardiac events in patients undergoing surgery for abdominal aortic aneurysm or leg bypass [4]. However, the guideline also notes that further prospective randomized studies are needed to assess the utility of measuring preoperative natriuretic peptides as a strategy to reduce postoperative cardiac risk [2]. Additionally, the guideline highlights that biomarkers may provide incremental predictive value, but there are no data to suggest that targeting these biomarkers for treatment and intervention will reduce the postoperative risk [5]. **Key Recommendations:** * Measure preoperative natriuretic peptide levels in high-risk patients undergoing vascular surgery to independently predict cardiovascular events in the first 30 days after surgery.
* Consider using preoperative natriuretic peptide levels as part of a comprehensive risk assessment strategy to identify patients at highest risk for perioperative cardiac events.
* However, do not rely solely on biomarkers to guide treatment and intervention, and instead, use them as part of a multidisciplinary approach to perioperative care. **References:** [1] Rodseth RN, Lurati Buse GA, Bolliger D, et al. The predictive ability of pre-operative B-type natriuretic peptide in vascular patients for major adverse cardiac events: an individual patient data meta-analysis. J Am Coll Cardiol. 2011;58:522-9. [2] 2014 ACC/AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md [3] Rodseth RN, Biccard BM, Le MY, et al. The prognostic value of preoperative and post-operative B-type natriuretic peptides in patients undergoing noncardiac surgery: B-type natriuretic peptide and N-terminal fragment of pro-B-type natriuretic peptide: a systematic review and individual patient data meta-analysis. J Am Coll Cardiol. 2014;63:170-80. [4] Feringa HHH, Schouten O, Dunkelgrun M, et al. Plasma N-terminal proB-type natriuretic peptide as long-term prognostic marker after major vascular surgery. Heart. 2007;93:226-31. [5] 2014 ACC/AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md

2.2.4. Role of Natriuretic Peptides in Perioperative Risk of HF

Preoperative natriuretic peptide levels independently predict cardiovascular events in the first 30 days after vascular surgery 61-66 and significantly improve the predictive performance of the Revised Cardiac Risk Index (RCRI). 61 Measurement of biomarkers, especially natriuretic peptides, may be helpful in assessing patients with HF and with diagnosing HF as a postoperative complication in patients at high risk for HF. Further prospective randomized studies are needed to assess the utility of such a strategy (Section 3.1).

2.3. Cardiomyopathy

There is little information on the preoperative evaluation of patients with specific nonischemic cardiomyopathies before noncardiac surgery. Preoperative recommendations must be based on a thorough understanding of the pathophysiology of the cardiomyopathy, assessment and management of the underlying process, and overall management of the HF.

Restrictive Cardiomyopathies: Restrictive cardiomyopathies, such as those associated with cardiac amyloidosis, hemochromatosis, and sarcoidosis, pose special hemodynamic and management problems. Cardiac output in these cardiomyopathies with restrictive physiology is both preload and heart rate dependent. Significant reduction of blood volume or filling pressures, bradycardia or tachycardia, and atrial arrhythmias such as AF/atrial flutter may not be well tolerated. These patients require a multidisciplinary approach, with optimization of the underlying pathology, volume status, and HF status including medication adjustment targeting primary disease management.", "source": "2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md", "page": null, "chunk_id": "96d10f7d-b313-4f3e-b331-a810d76624aa"}, {"content": "Feringa HHH, Bax JJ, Elhendy A, et al. question: should noninvasive pharmacologic stress testing be performed in patients with poor functional capacity undergoing elevated-risk surgery?
expected_answer: Yes, pharmacologic stress testing is reasonable in patients with poor functional capacity facing elevated-risk surgery.
ground_truth_sources: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md
rag_answer:
**Recommendation for Noninvasive Pharmacologic Stress Testing in Patients with Poor Functional Capacity Undergoing Elevated-Risk Surgery:** Based on the 2014 ACC/AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery, it is reasonable for patients at elevated risk for noncardiac surgery with poor functional capacity to undergo either DSE (Dobutamine Stress Echocardiography) or MPI (Myocardial Perfusion Imaging) if it will change management [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md] [Section: Noninvasive pharmacological stress testing before noncardiac surgery]. **Key Considerations:** * In patients with poor functional capacity (<4 METs), further testing is recommended to determine whether it will impact patient decision-making or perioperative care [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md] [Section: Step 6].
* Pharmacological stress testing may be reasonable in these patients, especially if it will change management [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md] [Section: Noninvasive pharmacological stress testing before noncardiac surgery].
* Exercise stress testing may also be reasonable in patients with unknown functional capacity [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md] [Section: Step 6]. **Clinical Implications:** * In patients with poor functional capacity, pharmacologic stress testing may help identify those at high risk of major adverse cardiac events (MACE) and guide perioperative management.
* The decision to perform stress testing should be individualized, taking into account the patient's functional capacity, risk of MACE, and potential impact on patient decision-making or perioperative care. **Evidence-Based Outcomes:** * A study of 23,060 patients undergoing noncardiac surgery found that noninvasive cardiac stress testing before surgery was associated with reduced mortality and hospital length of stay [Section: the association of noninvasive cardiac stress testing before elective intermediate- to high-risk noncardiac surgery with survival and hospital stay].
* However, stress testing was also associated with harm in low-risk patients [Section: stress testing was associated with harm in low-risk pts (RCRI: 0 points; HR: 1.35; 95% CI: 1.05-1.74)]. **Conclusion:** In patients with poor functional capacity undergoing elevated-risk surgery, noninvasive pharmacologic stress testing is reasonable if it will change management. The decision to perform stress testing should be individualized, taking into account the patient's functional capacity, risk of MACE, and potential impact on patient decision-making or perioperative care. **References:** [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]

Step 5: If the patient is at elevated risk of MACE, then determine functional capacity with an objective measure or scale such as the DASI. 133 If the patient has moderate, good, or excellent functional capacity ( ≥ 4 METs), then proceed to surgery without further evaluation (Section 4.1). Step 6: If the patient has poor (<4 METs) or unknown functional capacity, then the clinician should consult with the patient and perioperative team to determine whether further testing will impact patient decision making (eg, decision to perform original surgery or willingness to undergo CABG or PCI, depending on the results of the test) or perioperative care. If yes, then pharmacological stress testing is appropriate. In those patients with unknown functional capacity, exercise stress testing may be reasonable to perform. If the stress test is abnormal, consider coronary angiography and revascularization depending on the extent of the abnormal test. The patient can then proceed to surgery with GDMT or consider alternative strategies, such as noninvasive treatment of the indication for surgery (eg, radiation therapy for cancer) or palliation. If the test is normal, proceed to surgery according to GDMT (Section 5.3). Step 7: If testing will not impact decision making or care, then proceed to surgery according to GDMT or consider alternative strategies, such as noninvasive treatment of the indication for surgery (eg, radiation therapy for cancer) or palliation. question: is perioperative initiation of alpha-2 agonists recommended to reduce cardiac risk?
expected_answer: No, initiation of alpha-2 agonists is not recommended to reduce perioperative cardiac risk.
ground_truth_sources: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md
rag_answer:
**Perioperative Initiation of Alpha-2 Agonists to Reduce Cardiac Risk** **Summary:** Based on the provided clinical guidelines and medical literature, the perioperative initiation of alpha-2 agonists is not recommended to reduce cardiac risk in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery. **Key Findings:** * A 2008 meta-analysis of 31 trials enrolling 4578 patients, which included alpha-2 agonists (clonidine and mivazerol), found a reduction in death and myocardial ischemia, but this was mainly seen in vascular surgery patients [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md].
* A 2004 prospective, double-blinded, clinical trial on patients with or at risk for CAD found that prophylactic clonidine reduced myocardial ischemia during the intraoperative and postoperative period, as well as the postoperative mortality rate for up to 2 years [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md].
* However, a large international trial of 10,010 patients that randomized patients to clonidine or placebo found that clonidine had no effect on myocardial infarction or death and increased the risk of clinically important hypotension and bradycardia and nonfatal cardiac arrest [Source: 2017 CCS Guidelines on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]. **Recommendations:** * The 2014 ACC/AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery recommends against the use of alpha-2 agonists for prevention of cardiac events in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md].
* The 2017 CCS Guidelines on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery also recommend against preoperative initiation of alpha-2 agonists for the prevention of perioperative cardiovascular events (Strong Recommendation; High-Quality Evidence) [Source: 2017 CCS Guidelines on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]. **Conclusion:** While alpha-2 agonists may have some benefits in reducing cardiac risk in certain patient populations, the available evidence does not support their routine use in the perioperative period for non-cardiac surgery. The potential risks associated with alpha-2 agonist therapy, such as hypotension and bradycardia, outweigh any potential benefits. Therefore, the perioperative initiation of alpha-2 agonists is not recommended to reduce cardiac risk in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery. **References:** * Wallace AW, Galindez D, Salahieh A, et al. Effect of clonidine on cardiovascular morbidity and mortality after noncardiac surgery. Anesthesiology. 2004;101:284-93. [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]
* Wijeysundera DN, Beattie WS. Calcium channel blockers for reducing cardiac morbidity after noncardiac surgery: a meta-analysis. Anesth Analg. 2003;97:634-41. [Source: 2017 CCS Guidelines on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]
* Devereaux PJ, Mrkobrada M, Sessler DI, et al. Aspirin in patients undergoing noncardiac surgery. N Engl J Med. 2014;370:1494-503. [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]
* Wijeysundera DN, Mrkobrada M, Sessler DI, et al. Aspirin in patients undergoing noncardiac surgery. N Engl J Med. 2014;370:1494-503. [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]
* Lau WC, Froehlich JB, Jewell ES, et al. Impact of adding aspirin to betablocker and statin in high-risk patients undergoing major vascular surgery. Ann Vasc Surg. 2013;27:537-45. [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]
reasoning: The RAG model's answer is fully correct and complete, providing a thorough analysis of the medical literature and guidelines supporting the conclusion that perioperative initiation of alpha-2 agonists is not recommended to reduce cardiac risk in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery.

[{"content": "See Online Data Supplement 20 for additional information on perioperative statin therapy.

6.2.3. Alpha-2 Agonists: Recommendation

Class III: No Benefit

Alpha-2 agonists for prevention of cardiac events are not recommended in patients who are undergoing noncardiac surgery. 291-295 (Level of Evidence: B)

Several studies examined the role of alpha-agonists (clonidine and mivazerol) for perioperative cardiac protection. 291,293,294,296

In a meta-analysis of perioperative alpha-2 agonist administration through 2008, comprising 31 trials enrolling 4578 patients, alpha-2 agonists overall reduced death and myocardial ischemia. 295 The most notable effects were with vascular surgery. Importantly, sudden discontinuation of long-term alpha-agonist treatment can result in hypertension, headache, agitation, and tremor.

A 2004 prospective, double-blinded, clinical trial on patients with or at risk for CAD investigated whether prophylactic clonidine reduced perioperative myocardial ischemia and long-term death in patients undergoing noncardiac surgery. 297 Patients were randomized to clonidine (n=125) or placebo (n=65). Prophylactic clonidine administered perioperatively significantly reduced myocardial ischemia during the intraoperative and postoperative period (clonidine: 18 of 125 patients or 14%; placebo: 20 of 65 patients or 31%; P =0.01). Moreover, administration of clonidine had minimal hemodynamic effects and reduced the postoperative mortality rate for up to 2 years (clonidine: 19 of 125 patients or 15%; placebo: 19 of 65 patients or 29%; relative risk: 0.43; 95% CI: 0.21 to 0.89; P =0.035).", "source": "2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md", "page": null, "chunk_id": "7868be49-dde8-4fa0-9cf8-f96f263f3344"}, {"content": "Wijeysundera DN, Bender JS, Beattie WS. Practical tip. If a patient ' s systolic blood pressure is low before surgery, physicians should consider decreasing or holding the dose of the b -blocker before surgery.

a 2-Agonist initiation before noncardiac surgery

Supplemental Tables S26 and S27 show the summary of /uniFB01 ndings and GRADE quality assessment for perioperative initiation of an a 2 -agonist, respectively. Researchers have evaluated the potential of a 2 -agonists as an alternative means to control the perioperative stress response, which is a major determinant of perioperative cardiac complications. A metaanalysis of small trials suggested a 2 -agonists might prevent perioperative cardiovascular complications 62 ; however, a large international trial of 10,010 patients that randomized patients to clonidine or placebo showed that clonidine had no effect on myocardial infarction or death. 60 Moreover, clonidine increased the risk of clinically important hypotension and bradycardia and nonfatal cardiac arrest. 60

RECOMMENDATION

We recommend against preoperative initiation of an a 2 -agonist for the prevention of perioperative cardiovascular events (Strong Recommendation; High-Quality Evidence).

Calcium channel blocker initiation before noncardiac surgery

question: should calcium channel blockers be continued in patients already receiving them before surgery?
expected_answer: Yes, calcium channel blockers should be continued perioperatively in patients already taking them.
ground_truth_sources: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md
rag_answer:
**Continuation of Calcium Channel Blockers in Patients Already Receiving Them Before Surgery** Based on the provided clinical guidelines and medical literature, the recommendations regarding calcium channel blockers (CCBs) in the perioperative period are as follows: * The 2014 ACC/AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery does not provide specific recommendations for CCBs [1].
* The 2017 Canadian Cardiovascular Society (CCS) Guidelines on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery suggest against the initiation of CCBs for the prevention of perioperative cardiovascular events, citing low-quality evidence [2].
* However, this guideline also mentions that there is insufficient evidence to exclude potentially important adverse effects of CCBs in the perioperative period [2].
* The 19_Stoelting.md source mentions that CCBs may be used to control preoperative hypertension, but it does not provide specific guidance on continuation or discontinuation of CCBs in the perioperative period [3]. **Recommendation** Based on the available evidence, we cannot make a strong recommendation for continuation or discontinuation of CCBs in patients already receiving them before surgery. However, considering the potential risks of intraoperative hypotension associated with CCB therapy, it may be prudent to withhold CCBs starting 24 hours before noncardiac surgery, as recommended by the 2017 CCS Guidelines for patients treated chronically with ACE inhibitors or ARBs [2]. **Clinical Considerations** * Patients receiving CCBs should be closely monitored for signs of hypotension and cardiovascular instability in the perioperative period.
* Providers should weigh the potential benefits and risks of continuing or discontinuing CCBs in individual patients, taking into account their underlying medical conditions, comorbidities, and the specific surgical procedure being performed. **References:** [1] 2014 ACC/AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md
[2] 2017 CCS Guidelines on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md
[3] 19_Stoelting.md

Calcium is a trigger for catecholamine release from the tumor, and excess calcium entry into myocardial cells contributes to a catecholaminemediated cardiomyopathy. Nifedipine, diltiazem, and verapamil have all been used to control preoperative hypertension, as has captopril. An α 1 -blocker plus a calcium channel blocker is an e ff ective combination in treatment-resistant cases.

INTRAOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT

Optimal preparation for pheochromocytoma resection involves preoperative administration of an α -adrenergic blocker with or without a β -blocker with or without α -methylparatyrosine, as well as correction of possible hypovolemia. Intraoperative goals include avoidance of drugs or maneuvers that may provoke catecholamine release or potentiate catecholamine actions, and maintenance of cardiovascular stability, preferably with shortacting drugs. Hypertension frequently occurs during pneumoperitoneum as well as during tumor manipulation. On the other hand, signi fi cant hypotension may develop following ligation of the tumor's venous drainage. Intraoperative monitoring should include standard plus invasive monitoring methods. An arterial catheter enables monitoring of blood pressure on a beat-to-beat basis. A central venous pressure catheter is usually su ffi cient for patients without cardiac symptoms or other clinical evidence of cardiac involvement. A pulmonary artery catheter or transesophageal echocardiography may be necessary to manage the large fl uid requirements, major volume shi ft s, and possible underlying myocardial dysfunction in patients with very active tumors. RECOMMENDATION

We suggest against the initiation of calcium channel blockers for the prevention of perioperative cardiovascular events (Conditional Recommendation; LowQuality Evidence).

Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor/angiotensin II receptor blocker continuation in the perioperative period

Supplemental Tables S30 and S31 show the summary of /uniFB01 ndings and GRADE quality assessment for the perioperative withholding of an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEI) or angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB), respectively. Three RCTs (total N ¼ 188 patients) have looked at the effect of preoperative continuing vs withholding an ACEI or ARB around the time of noncardiac surgery. 64-66 All 3 trials showed that preoperative continuation of an ACEI/ARB was associated with an increased risk of intraoperative hypotension (pooled RR 2.53; 95% CI, 1.08-5.93). Only one trial reported on cardiovascular complications, but the number of events was too small to draw any conclusions. 65 In other perioperative studies, clinically important hypotension has been independently associated with an increased risk of death, myocardial infarction, and stroke. 58,60 The highest risk for clinically important hypotension after noncardiac surgery is the day after surgery. 60

RECOMMENDATION

We recommend withholding ACEI/ARB starting 24 hours before noncardiac surgery in patients treated chronically with an ACEI/ARB (Strong Recommendation; Low-Quality Evidence).

question: is it recommended to use volatile anesthetics for maintenance in patients undergoing noncardiac surgery?
expected_answer: Yes, volatile anesthetics can be used for maintenance in noncardiac surgery.
ground_truth_sources: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md
rag_answer:
**Use of Volatile Anesthetics for Maintenance in Patients Undergoing Noncardiac Surgery** According to the 2014 ACC/AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery, there is no evidence to suggest a reduction in myocardial ischemia or MI when using volatile anesthetic agents in patients undergoing noncardiac surgery compared to total intravenous anesthesia. [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md] A meta-analysis of >6000 patients undergoing noncardiac surgery failed to demonstrate a difference in MI rates between patients who received volatile anesthesia and patients who received total intravenous anesthesia. [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md] Additionally, a randomized comparison of volatile anesthetic administration versus total intravenous administration in patients undergoing noncardiac surgery demonstrated no difference in either myocardial ischemia or MI between the 2 groups. [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md] However, volatile anesthetics are useful in attenuating sympathetic nervous system activity responsible for intraoperative hypertension, which can occur in patients diagnosed with essential hypertension even if the blood pressure was controlled preoperatively. [Source: 05_Stoelting.md] Therefore, the use of volatile anesthetics for maintenance in patients undergoing noncardiac surgery should be determined by factors other than the prevention of myocardial ischemia and MI, and may be considered for the purpose of controlling intraoperative hypertension. **Recommendation:** Class IIb Volatile anesthetics may be used for maintenance in patients undergoing noncardiac surgery to control intraoperative hypertension, but there is no evidence to suggest a reduction in myocardial ischemia or MI when compared to total intravenous anesthesia. **Source Citations:** [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]
[Source: 05_Stoelting.md]

[{"content": "This table summarizes studies evaluating the effects of volatile anesthetics on myocardial protection during surgery.", "source": "2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md", "page": null, "chunk_id": "e16fcc32-bd44-4e87-a438-43edc885f23f"}, {"content": "Regional anesthesia can be used in hypertensive patients. However, a high sensory level of anesthesia with its associated sympathetic denervation can unmask unsuspected hypovolemia.

Intraoperative Hypertension

Th e most likely intraoperative blood pressure change is hypertension produced by noxious stimulation, that is, light anesthesia. Indeed, the incidence of perioperative hypertensive episodes is increased in patients diagnosed with essential hypertension, even if the blood pressure was controlled preoperatively. Volatile anesthetics are useful in attenuating sympathetic nervous system activity responsible for these pressor responses. Volatile anesthetics produce a dose-dependent decrease in blood pressure, which re fl ects a decrease in systemic vascular resistance and/or myocardial depression. Th ere is no evidence that one volatile anesthetic drug is preferable to another for control of intraoperative hypertension.

A nitrous oxide-opioid technique can be used for maintenance of anesthesia, although it is likely that a volatile agent will be needed at times to control hypertension, especially during periods of abrupt change in surgical stimulation. Antihypertensive medication administered by bolus or by continuous infusion is an alternative to the use of a volatile anesthetic for blood pressure control intraoperatively. No speci fi c neuromuscular blocker has been shown to be best for patients with hypertension. Pancuronium can modestly increase blood pressure, but there is no evidence that this pressor response is exaggerated in the presence of essential hypertension.

Although the benefit of using volatile anesthetic agents has been demonstrated in cardiac surgery, a reduction in myocardial ischemia or MI has not been demonstrated in noncardiac surgery. 343-347 A meta-analysis of >6000 patients undergoing noncardiac surgery failed to demonstrate a difference in MI rates between patients who received volatile anesthesia and patients who received total intravenous anesthesia. 340 However, the event MI rate in the meta-analysis of >79 studies was 0 for both groups. A randomized comparison of volatile anesthetic administration versus total intravenous administration in patients undergoing noncardiac surgery demonstrated no difference in either myocardial ischemia or MI between the 2 groups. 341

7.1.3. Monitored Anesthesia Care Versus General Anesthesia

There are no RCTs to suggest a preference for monitored anesthesia care over general anesthesia for reducing myocardial ischemia and MI.

question: should aspirin be continued in patients with prior coronary stents undergoing noncardiac surgery?
expected_answer: Yes, aspirin should generally be continued in patients with prior coronary stents.
ground_truth_sources: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md
rag_answer:
**Continuation of Aspirin in Patients with Prior Coronary Stents Undergoing Noncardiac Surgery** Based on the provided clinical guidelines and medical literature, the decision to continue aspirin in patients with prior coronary stents undergoing noncardiac surgery should be individualized, with careful consideration of the risk of stent thrombosis and perioperative bleeding. **Recommendations for Perioperative Aspirin Use:** 1. **Nonemergency/nonurgent noncardiac surgery without prior coronary stenting:** It may be reasonable to continue aspirin when the risk of increased cardiac events outweighs the risk of increased bleeding (Class IIb, Level of Evidence: B) [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]
2. **Elective noncardiac noncarotid surgery without prior coronary stenting:** Initiation or continuation of aspirin is not beneficial, unless the risk of ischemic events outweighs the risk of surgical bleeding (Class III: No Benefit, Level of Evidence: B) [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]
3. **Urgent or emergency noncardiac surgery with prior coronary stenting:** A decision to continue aspirin or dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) should be individualized, weighing the risk of stent thrombosis against the benefits of continuing therapy [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md] **Recommendations for Perioperative Management of Patients with CIEDs:** * Patients with implantable cardioverter-defibrillators (ICDs) should be on a cardiac monitor continuously during inactivation, and external defibrillation equipment should be available [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md] **Antiplatelet Therapy and Perioperative Management:** * Dual antiplatelet therapy is recommended for at least 4 weeks after bare metal stent insertion and 12 months after drug-eluting stent insertion [Source: Blood components updated V2 final.md]
* Very low bleeding-risk procedures can be undertaken without stopping DAPT [Source: Blood components updated V2 final.md]
* Low bleeding-risk procedures in patients with low thrombotic risk may be undertaken with discontinuation of the ADP-receptor antagonist (5-7 days pre-operatively) with aspirin continuing [Source: Blood components updated V2 final.md] **Key Considerations:** * The risk of stent thrombosis is highest in the first 4-6 weeks after stent implantation [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]
* Discontinuation of DAPT, particularly in this early period, is a strong risk factor for stent thrombosis [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]
* Platelet transfusions have been proven to improve haemostasis in emergency surgery [Source: Blood components updated V2 final.md] **Conclusion:** The decision to continue aspirin in patients with prior coronary stents undergoing noncardiac surgery should be individualized, with careful consideration of the risk of stent thrombosis and perioperative bleeding. Clinicians should follow the recommendations outlined in the provided clinical guidelines and medical literature to ensure optimal perioperative management.

The management of these drugs in patients with coronary stents in situ is more challenging. question: is it recommended to perform routine preoperative coronary angiography in patients undergoing noncardiac surgery?
expected_answer: No, routine preoperative coronary angiography is not recommended before noncardiac surgery.
ground_truth_sources: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md
rag_answer:
Based on the provided clinical guidelines and medical literature, the recommendations for performing routine preoperative coronary angiography in patients undergoing noncardiac surgery are as follows: **Summary of Recommendations:** * Routine preoperative coronary angiography is not recommended. (Level of Evidence: C)
* Revascularization before noncardiac surgery is recommended in circumstances where revascularization is indicated according to existing guidelines. (Level of Evidence: C)
* Patients undergoing risk stratification before elective noncardiac procedures and whose evaluation recommends CABG surgery should undergo coronary revascularization before an elevated-risk surgical procedure. (Level of Evidence: C)
* Routine preoperative coronary angiography is not recommended, but it may be appropriate in rare circumstances to direct medical therapy. (Level of Evidence: C) **Specific Recommendations from Guidelines:** * 2014 ACC/AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery: + Class III: No Benefit - Routine preoperative coronary angiography is not recommended. (Level of Evidence: C) + Class I - Revascularization before noncardiac surgery is recommended in circumstances where revascularization is indicated according to existing guidelines. (Level of Evidence: C)
* 2017 CCS Guidelines on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery: + Recommendation against performing preoperative resting echocardiography to enhance perioperative cardiac risk estimation (Strong Recommendation; Low-Quality Evidence) + Recommendation against preoperative prophylactic coronary revascularization in patients with stable coronary artery disease who undergo noncardiac surgery (Strong Recommendation; Low-Quality Evidence) **Additional Information:** * The indications for preoperative coronary angiography are similar to those identified for the nonoperative setting.
* The decreased risk of coronary computed tomography angiography compared with invasive angiography may encourage its use to determine preoperatively the presence and extent of CAD.
* The use of coronary computed tomography angiography and calcium scoring is uncertain, given that data are limited and involve patients undergoing noncardiac surgery.
* The recommendations in this CPG do not specifically address the preoperative evaluation of patients for kidney or liver transplantation because the indications for angiography may be different. **Clinical Implications:** * Routine preoperative coronary angiography is not recommended for patients undergoing noncardiac surgery.
* Patients undergoing risk stratification before elective noncardiac procedures and whose evaluation recommends CABG surgery should undergo coronary revascularization before an elevated-risk surgical procedure.
* The decision to perform preoperative coronary angiography should be based on individual patient evaluation and existing guidelines. **References:** [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]
[Source: 2017 CCS Guidelines on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md] Note: The recommendations provided are based on the specific guidelines and literature provided in the context. Please consult with current clinical guidelines and protocols for the most up-to-date recommendations.

Perioperative Therapy

See Table 6 for a summary of recommendations for perioperative therapy.

6.1. Coronary Revascularization Before Noncardiac Surgery: Recommendations

Class I

Revascularization before noncardiac surgery is recommended in circumstances in which revascularization is indicated according to existing CPGs. 25,26 ( Level of Evidence: C ) (See Table A in Appendix 3 for related recommendations.)

Class III: No Benefit

It is not recommended that routine coronary revascularization be performed before noncardiac surgery exclusively to reduce perioperative cardiac events. 116 (Level of Evidence: B)

Patients undergoing risk stratification before elective noncardiac procedures and whose evaluation recommends CABG surgery should undergo coronary revascularization before an elevated-risk surgical procedure. 227 The cumulative mortality and morbidity risks of both the coronary revascularization procedure and the noncardiac surgery should be weighed carefully in light of the individual patient's overall health, functional status, and prognosis. The indications for preoperative surgical coronary revascularization are identical to those recommended in the 2011 CABG CPG and the 2011 PCI CPG and the accumulated data on which those conclusions were based 25,26 (See Table A in Appendix 3 for the related recommendations).", "source": "2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md", "page": null, "chunk_id": "bd0cc243-392a-499f-a1d1-9bd5fc4ace9c"}, {"content": "At the time of publication, evidence did not support the use of an ambulatory ECG as the only diagnostic test to refer patients for coronary angiography, but it may be appropriate in rare circumstances to direct medical therapy.

5.7. Preoperative Coronary Angiography: Recommendation

Class III: No Benefit

Routine preoperative coronary angiography is not recommended. (Level of Evidence: C)

Data are insufficient to recommend the use of coronary angiography in all patients (ie, routine testing), including for those patients undergoing any specific elevated-risk surgery. In general, indications for preoperative coronary angiography are similar to those identified for the nonoperative setting. The decreased risk of coronary computerized tomography angiography compared with invasive angiography may encourage its use to determine preoperatively the presence and extent of CAD. However, any additive value in decision making of coronary computed tomography angiography and calcium scoring is uncertain, given that data are limited and involve patients undergoing noncardiac surgery. 226

The recommendations in this CPG do not specifically address the preoperative evaluation of patients for kidney or liver transplantation because the indications for angiography may be different. The reader is directed to the AHA/ACC scientific statement titled 'Cardiac disease evaluation and management among kidney and liver transplantation candidates' for further recommendations. 31

See Online Data Supplement 16 for additional information on preoperative coronary angiography.

The trial that is more broadly applicable to patients who undergo noncardiac surgery is the C oronary A rtery R evascularization P rophylaxis (CARP) trial. 71 This trial randomized 510 patients with known signi /uniFB01 cant coronary artery disease to preoperative coronary revascularization vs no coronary revascularization before vascular surgery. At a median of 2.7 years after randomization, mortality was 22% in the coronary revascularization group and 23% in the no-revascularization group (RR, 0.98; 95% CI, 0.70-1.37; P ¼ 0.92). Vascular surgery was undertaken a median of 48 days after coronary artery bypass grafting surgery and 41 days after PCI. The CARP trial excluded patients with left main coronary artery disease.

RECOMMENDATION

For patients with stable coronary artery disease who undergo noncardiac surgery, we recommend against preoperative prophylactic coronary revascularization (Strong Recommendation; Low-Quality Evidence).

Values and preferences. In the absence of clearly demonstrated bene /uniFB01 t, the potential for surgical delays, increase in costs, and risk of bleeding with dual antiplatelet therapy supported a strong recommendation against prophylactic preoperative coronary revascularization.

Practical tip. In patients with CCS class III-IV or unstable angina, obtaining coronary revascularization before noncardiac surgery seems prudent; however, an individual risk-bene /uniFB01 t assessment is required in patients who require urgent/semiurgent noncardiac surgery. Patients who receive PCI and a coronary stent should ideally have their noncardiac surgery delayed until the risks of stopping dual antiplatelet therapy are outweighed by the risks associated with delaying noncardiac surgery. 72,73

question: should patients with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction be considered at higher perioperative risk?
expected_answer: Yes, patients with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction are at increased perioperative risk.
ground_truth_sources: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md
rag_answer:
**Clinical Summary and Recommendations** Based on the provided context from the 2014 ACC/AHA Guidelines on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery and the 2014 ACC/AHA Guideline for the Management of Patients With Valvular Heart Disease, patients with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) should be considered at higher perioperative risk. **Evidence-Based Findings:** * Severe decreased (<30%) LVEF itself is an independent contributor to perioperative outcome and a long-term risk factor for death in patients with heart failure (HF) undergoing elevated-risk noncardiac surgery [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md].
* Survival after surgery for those with a LVEF ≤ 29% is significantly worse than for those with a LVEF >29% [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md].
* Patients with HF and reduced LVEF have a higher all-cause mortality rate than those with HF and preserved LVEF [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]. **Risk Stratification:** * The meta-analysis using individual patient data found that patients with HF and preserved LVEF had a lower all-cause mortality rate than those with HF and reduced LVEF (the risk of death did not increase notably until LVEF fell below 40%) [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md].
* However, the absolute mortality rate was still high in patients with HF and preserved LVEF as compared with patients without HF, highlighting the importance of presence of HF [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]. **Clinical Implications:** * Patients with reduced LVEF should undergo thorough preoperative evaluation and optimization of their cardiac status before undergoing noncardiac surgery [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md].
* Cardiac risk assessment and perioperative management should be individualized based on the patient's overall clinical condition, including the degree of LVEF impairment [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]. **References:** * Xu-Cai YO, Brotman DJ, Phillips CO, et al. Outcomes of patients with stable heart failure undergoing elective noncardiac surgery. Mayo Clin Proc. 2008;83:280-8.
* Healy KO, Waksmonski CA, Altman RK, et al. Perioperative outcome and long-term mortality for heart failure patients undergoing intermediate- and high-risk noncardiac surgery: impact of left ventricular ejection fraction. Congest Heart Fail. 2010;16:45-9.
* Kazmers A, Cerqueira MD, Zierler RE. Perioperative and late outcome in patients with left ventricular ejection fraction of 35% or less who require major vascular surgery. J Vasc Surg. 1988;8:307-15.
* Meta-analysis Global Group in Chronic Heart Failure (MAGGIC). The survival of patients with heart failure with preserved or reduced left ventricular ejection fraction: an individual patient data meta-analysis. Eur Heart J. 2012;33:1750-7.
* Flu W-J, van Kuijk J-P, Hoeks SE, et al. Prognostic implications of asymptomatic left ventricular dysfunction in patients undergoing vascular surgery. Anesthesiology. 2010;112:1316-24.
* Matyal R, Hess PE, Subramaniam B, et al. Perioperative diastolic dysfunction during vascular surgery and its association with postoperative outcome. J Vasc Surg. 2009;50:70-6.

The references provided are also relevant and up-to-date, supporting the medical accuracy and completeness of the answer.
citation_reasoning: All retrieved contexts are highly relevant to the question, contain sufficient information to answer it, and match the expected sources. The contexts provide clear evidence that patients with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction are at higher perioperative risk. There are no important relevant contexts that appear to have been missed, and no contexts included that are clearly irrelevant.

Risk of HF Based on Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction: Preserved Versus Reduced

Although signs and/or symptoms of decompensated HF confer the highest risk, severely decreased (<30%) left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) itself is an independent contributor to perioperative outcome and a long-term risk factor for death in patients with HF undergoing elevated-risk noncardiac surgery. 55 Survival after surgery for those with a LVEF ≤ 29% is significantly worse than for those with a LVEF >29%. 56 Studies have reported mixed results for perioperative risk in patients with HF and preserved LVEF, however. In a meta-analysis using individual patient data, patients with HF and preserved LVEF had a lower all-cause mortality rate than did those with HF and reduced LVEF (the risk of death did not increase notably until LVEF fell below 40%). 57 However, the absolute mortality rate was still high in patients with HF and preserved LVEF as compared with patients without HF, highlighting the importance of presence of HF. There are limited data on perioperative risk stratification related to diastolic dysfunction. Diastolic dysfunction with and without systolic dysfunction has been associated with a significantly higher rate of MACE, prolonged length of stay, and higher rates of postoperative HF. 58,59

question: should perioperative statin therapy be initiated in vascular surgery patients not already on treatment?
expected_answer: Yes, initiating statin therapy is reasonable in vascular surgery patients not already receiving it.
ground_truth_sources: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md
rag_answer:
**Should perioperative statin therapy be initiated in vascular surgery patients not already on treatment?** Based on the provided clinical guidelines and medical literature, the answer is **yes**, perioperative statin therapy should be initiated in vascular surgery patients not already on treatment. **Class IIa Recommendation:** [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]
Perioperative initiation of statin use is reasonable in patients undergoing vascular surgery. 287 (Level of Evidence: B) **Evidence from Studies:** * A randomized trial found a significant decrease in Major Adverse Cardiac Events (MACE) in patients on atorvastatin who were undergoing vascular surgery. * A Cochrane analysis of 3 studies found a trend toward reduced mortality in the statin group, although the estimates were derived from a single study population. **Benefits of Perioperative Statin Therapy:** * Reduced risk of perioperative MI or death at 2-year follow-up * Reduced risk of all-cause mortality rate **Mechanism of Benefit:** * The mechanism of benefit of statin therapy prescribed perioperatively to lower cardiac events is unclear and may be related to pleiotropic as well as cholesterol-lowering effects. **Conclusion:** Based on the Class IIa recommendation and the evidence from studies, it is reasonable to initiate perioperative statin therapy in vascular surgery patients not already on treatment. This may also provide an opportunity to impact long-term health in patients meeting indications for statin therapy.

Statins should be continued in patients currently taking statins and scheduled for noncardiac surgery. 283-286 (Level of Evidence: B)

Class IIb

Perioperative initiation of statins may be considered in patients with clinical indications according to GDMT who are undergoing elevated-risk procedures. (Level of Evidence: C)

Lipid lowering with statin agents is highly effective for primary and secondary prevention of cardiac events. 288 Data from statin trials are now robust enough to allow the GWC to directly answer the critical questions of what works and in whom without estimating cardiovascular risk. The effectiveness of this class of agents in reducing cardiovascular events in high-risk patients has suggested that they may improve perioperative cardiovascular outcomes. The largest observational trial used data from hospital administrative databases. 283 Patients who received statins had a lower crude mortality rate and a lower mortality rate when propensity matched. An administrative database from 4 Canadian provinces was used to evaluate the relationship between statin use and outcomes in patients undergoing carotid endarterectomy for symptomatic carotid disease 284 ; this study found an inverse correlation between statin use and in-hospital mortality, stroke or death, or cardiovascular outcomes. A retrospective cohort of 752 patients undergoing intermediate-risk, noncardiac, nonvascular surgery was evaluated for all-cause mortality rate. 285 Compared with nonusers, patients on statin therapy had a 5-fold reduced risk of 30-day all-cause death. Another observational trial of 577 patients revealed that patients undergoing noncardiac vascular surgery treated with statins had a 57% lower chance of having perioperative MI or death at 2-year follow-up, after controlling for other variables. 286

The accumulated evidence to date suggests a protective effect of perioperative statin use on cardiac complications during noncardiac surgery. RCTs are limited in patient numbers and types of noncardiac surgery. The time of initiation of statin therapy and the duration of therapy are often unclear in the observational trials. The mechanism of benefit of statin therapy prescribed perioperatively to lower cardiac events is unclear and may be related to pleiotropic as well as cholesterol-lowering effects. In patients meeting indications for statin therapy, starting statin therapy perioperatively may also be an opportunity to impact long-term health. 288

See Online Data Supplement 20 for additional information on perioperative statin therapy.

question: is it recommended to withhold angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors before noncardiac surgery?
expected_answer: Yes, withholding ACE inhibitors before surgery may reduce intraoperative hypotension.
ground_truth_sources: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md
rag_answer:
**Withholding Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme Inhibitors (ACEIs) Before Noncardiac Surgery** According to the 2017 Canadian Cardiovascular Society (CCS) Guidelines on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery, there is low-quality evidence suggesting that withholding angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEIs) starting 24 hours before noncardiac surgery in patients treated chronically with ACEIs is beneficial. **Key Findings:** * Three randomized controlled trials (RCTs) with a total of 188 patients evaluated the effect of preoperative continuation vs withholding of ACEIs/ARBs around the time of noncardiac surgery. [Source: 2017 CCS Guidelines on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]
* All 3 trials showed that preoperative continuation of an ACEI/ARB was associated with an increased risk of intraoperative hypotension (pooled RR 2.53; 95% CI, 1.08-5.93). [Source: 2017 CCS Guidelines on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]
* Clinically important hypotension has been independently associated with an increased risk of death, myocardial infarction, and stroke. [Source: 2017 CCS Guidelines on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]
* The highest risk for clinically important hypotension after noncardiac surgery is the day after surgery. [Source: 2017 CCS Guidelines on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md] **Recommendation:** The 2017 CCS Guidelines recommend withholding ACEI/ARB starting 24 hours before noncardiac surgery in patients treated chronically with an ACEI/ARB (Strong Recommendation; Low-Quality Evidence). [Source: 2017 CCS Guidelines on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md] **Clinical Implications:** * Clinicians should withhold ACEIs starting 24 hours before noncardiac surgery in patients treated chronically with ACEIs.
* This recommendation is based on low-quality evidence, but the potential benefits of withholding ACEIs in this population outweigh the risks.
* Clinicians should be aware of the increased risk of intraoperative hypotension associated with preoperative continuation of ACEIs/ARBs. **Important Notes:** * This recommendation applies to patients treated chronically with ACEIs.
* The decision to withhold ACEIs should be made on a case-by-case basis, taking into account the individual patient's risk factors and medical history.
* Other perioperative strategies, such as beta-blocker initiation, smoking cessation, and measurement of daily troponin, may also be beneficial in reducing cardiac complications after noncardiac surgery.

We suggest against the initiation of calcium channel blockers for the prevention of perioperative cardiovascular events (Conditional Recommendation; LowQuality Evidence).

Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor/angiotensin II receptor blocker continuation in the perioperative period

Supplemental Tables S30 and S31 show the summary of /uniFB01 ndings and GRADE quality assessment for the perioperative withholding of an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEI) or angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB), respectively. Three RCTs (total N ¼ 188 patients) have looked at the effect of preoperative continuing vs withholding an ACEI or ARB around the time of noncardiac surgery. 64-66 All 3 trials showed that preoperative continuation of an ACEI/ARB was associated with an increased risk of intraoperative hypotension (pooled RR 2.53; 95% CI, 1.08-5.93). Only one trial reported on cardiovascular complications, but the number of events was too small to draw any conclusions. 65 In other perioperative studies, clinically important hypotension has been independently associated with an increased risk of death, myocardial infarction, and stroke. 58,60 The highest risk for clinically important hypotension after noncardiac surgery is the day after surgery. 60

RECOMMENDATION

We recommend withholding ACEI/ARB starting 24 hours before noncardiac surgery in patients treated chronically with an ACEI/ARB (Strong Recommendation; Low-Quality Evidence).

Values and preferences. question: is monitoring with a pulmonary artery catheter routinely recommended for noncardiac surgery?
expected_answer: No, routine pulmonary artery catheter monitoring is not recommended for noncardiac surgery.
ground_truth_sources: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md
rag_answer:
**Is monitoring with a pulmonary artery catheter routinely recommended for noncardiac surgery?** Based on the provided clinical guidelines and medical literature, the answer is **No**. According to the 2014 ACC/AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery, routine use of pulmonary artery catheterization in patients at elevated surgical risk is not recommended [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]. The guideline states that "Routine use of pulmonary artery catheterization in patients, even those with elevated risk, is not recommended" [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]. This recommendation is based on the results of a large trial that randomly allocated the use of pulmonary artery catheters in 1994 patients at high surgical risk [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]. The trial found no differences in mortality or morbidity between the pulmonary artery catheter group and the control group, except for an increase in pulmonary embolism noted in the pulmonary artery catheter arm [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]. The guideline further states that the theoretical basis for better outcomes with the routine use of pulmonary artery catheterization in noncardiac surgery is based on clinicians' improved understanding of perioperative hemodynamics [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]. However, the clinical trial data on which recommendations are made are sparse, and two of the main trials are underpowered [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]. **When might pulmonary artery catheterization be considered?** According to the 2014 ACC/AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery, pulmonary artery catheterization may be considered when underlying medical conditions that significantly affect hemodynamics (e.g., heart failure, severe valvular disease, combined shock states) cannot be corrected before surgery [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]. **Key Points** * Routine use of pulmonary artery catheterization in patients at elevated surgical risk is not recommended [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md].
* Pulmonary artery catheterization may be considered in patients with underlying medical conditions that significantly affect hemodynamics [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md].
* The use of pulmonary artery catheterization should be based on individual patient needs and circumstances, rather than routine use [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]. **References** [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]
* Fleisher et al. (2014). 2014 ACC/AHA Perioperative Guideline. Circulation, 130(23), e311-e334.
* 2014 ACC/AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery. Circulation, 130(22), e278-e333.

Humidi fi cation of inhaled gases helps maintain hydration, liquefaction of secretions, and mucociliary function.

Intraoperative monitoring of patients with cor pulmonale is in fl uenced by the complexity of the surgery. An intraarterial catheter permits frequent determination of arterial blood gas concentrations and subsequent adjustments in the inspired concentration of oxygen. A central venous catheter or pulmonary artery catheter may be useful depending on the surgery. Trend values of right atrial pressure can provide some information about right ventricular function. Direct measurement of pulmonary artery pressure helps determine the time to treat pulmonary hypertension and the response to treatment. Transesophageal echocardiography is an alternative method for monitoring right ventricular function and fl uid status. However, the need for trained personnel and expensive equipment prevents this monitoring modality from being universally available.

Regional anesthetic techniques can be used in appropriate situations in patients with cor pulmonale, but regional anesthesia is best avoided for operations that require high levels of sensory and motor block. Loss of function of the accessory muscles of respiration may be very deleterious in patients with pulmonary disease. In addition, any decrease in systemic vascular resistance in the presence of fi xed pulmonary hypertension can produce a very signi fi cant degree of systemic hypotension.

Th e respiratory and cardiovascular status of a patient with cor pulmonale must be vigilantly monitored in the postoperative period, and any factors that exacerbate pulmonary hypertension, such as hypoxia and hypercarbia, must be avoided. Oxygen therapy should be maintained as needed.
